user-invalid-pseudo.name: -moz-ui-invalid
user-invalid-pseudo.summary: The :-moz-ui-invalid CSS pseudo-class represents any validated form element whose value isn't valid based on their validation constraints, in certain circumstances. This pseudo-class is applied according to the following rules:
user-invalid-pseudo.title: :-moz-ui-invalid

active-pseudo.name: active
active-pseudo.summary: The :active CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as a button) that is being activated by the user.
active-pseudo.title: :active

adjacent-sibling-combinators.name: adjacent_sibling
adjacent-sibling-combinators.summary: The adjacent sibling combinator (+) separates two selectors and matches the second element only if it immediately follows the first element, and both are children of the same parent element.

notes: Internet Explorer 7 doesn't update the style correctly when an element is dynamically placed before an element that matched the selector.
In Internet Explorer 8, if an element is inserted dynamically by clicking on a link the first-child style isn't applied until the link loses focus.

adjacent-sibling-combinators.title: Adjacent sibling combinator

the-any-link-pseudo.name: any-link
the-any-link-pseudo.summary: The :any-link CSS pseudo-class selector represents an element that acts as the source anchor of a hyperlink, independent of whether it has been visited. In other words, it matches every <a>, <area>, or <link> element that has an href attribute. Thus, it matches all elements that match :link or :visited.
the-any-link-pseudo.title: :any-link

attribute-selectors.name: attribute
attribute-selectors.summary: The CSS attribute selector matches elements based on the presence or value of a given attribute.
attribute-selectors.title: Attribute selectors

blank-pseudo.name: blank
blank-pseudo.summary: The :blank CSS pseudo-class selects empty user input elements (eg. <input> or <textarea>).
blank-pseudo.title: :blank

checked.name: checked
checked.summary: The :checked CSS pseudo-class selector represents any radio (<input type="radio">), checkbox (<input type="checkbox">), or option (<option> in a <select>) element that is checked or toggled to an on state.

chrome.notes: On macOS, styling <option&rt; elements has no effect.

notes: From Firefox 56, <option&rt; elements cannot be styled.
On macOS, styling <option&rt; elements has no effect.

firefox_android.notes: From Firefox 56, <option&rt; elements cannot be styled.

opera.notes: On macOS, styling <option&rt; elements has no effect.

edge_blink.notes: On macOS, styling <option&rt; elements has no effect.

checked.title: :checked

child-combinators.name: child
child-combinators.summary: The child combinator (>) is placed between two CSS selectors. It matches only those elements matched by the second selector that are the direct children of elements matched by the first.
child-combinators.title: Child combinator

class-html.name: class
class-html.summary: The CSS class selector matches elements based on the contents of their class attribute.
class-html.title: Class selectors

the-column-combinator.name: column
the-column-combinator.summary: The column combinator (||) is placed between two CSS selectors. It matches only those elements matched by the second selector that belong to the column elements matched by the first.
the-column-combinator.title: Column combinator

default-pseudo.name: default
default-pseudo.summary: The :default CSS pseudo-class selects form elements that are the default in a group of related elements.
default-pseudo.title: :default

descendant-combinators.name: descendant
descendant-combinators.summary: The descendant combinator — typically represented by a single space ( ) character — combines two selectors such that elements matched by the second selector are selected if they have an ancestor (parent, parent's parent, parent's parent's parent, etc) element matching the first selector. Selectors that utilize a descendant combinator are called descendant selectors.

chrome.notes: >>> is aliased to this selector since its use as the 'shadow-piercing descendant combinator' was deprecated.

chrome_android.notes: >>> is aliased to this selector since its use as the 'shadow-piercing descendant combinator' was deprecated.

samsunginternet_android.notes: >>> is aliased to this selector since its use as the 'shadow-piercing descendant combinator' was deprecated.

webview_android.notes: >>> is aliased to this selector since its use as the 'shadow-piercing descendant combinator' was deprecated.

edge_blink.notes: >>> is aliased to this selector since its use as the 'shadow-piercing descendant combinator' was deprecated.

descendant-combinators.title: Descendant combinator

the-dir-pseudo.name: dir
the-dir-pseudo.summary: The :dir() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on the directionality of the text contained in them.
the-dir-pseudo.title: :dir()

enableddisabled.name: disabled
enableddisabled.summary: The :disabled CSS pseudo-class represents any disabled element. An element is disabled if it can't be activated (selected, clicked on, typed into, etc.) or accept focus. The element also has an enabled state, in which it can be activated or accept focus.

ie.notes: Internet Explorer does not recognize :disabled on the <fieldset> element.

enableddisabled.title: :disabled

enableddisabled.name: enabled
enableddisabled.summary: The :enabled CSS pseudo-class represents any enabled element. An element is enabled if it can be activated (selected, clicked on, typed into, etc.) or accept focus. The element also has a disabled state, in which it can't be activated or accept focus.
enableddisabled.title: :enabled

the-empty-pseudo.name: empty
the-empty-pseudo.summary: The :empty CSS pseudo-class represents any element that has no children. Children can be either element nodes or text (including whitespace). Comments, processing instructions, and CSS content do not affect whether an element is considered empty.
the-empty-pseudo.title: :empty

first-child-pseudo.name: first-child
first-child-pseudo.summary: The :first-child CSS pseudo-class represents the first element among a group of sibling elements.

notes: Internet Explorer 7 doesn't update :first-child styles when elements are added dynamically.
In Internet Explorer 8, if an element is inserted dynamically by clicking on a link, then the :first-child style isn't applied until the link loses focus.

first-child-pseudo.title: :first-child

first-of-type-pseudo.name: first-of-type
first-of-type-pseudo.summary: The :first-of-type CSS pseudo-class represents the first element of its type among a group of sibling elements.

ie.notes: Internet Explorer treats all unknown elements (such as custom elements) as the same element type.

first-of-type-pseudo.title: :first-of-type

the-focus-visible-pseudo.name: focus-visible
the-focus-visible-pseudo.summary: The :focus-visible pseudo-class applies while an element matches the :focus pseudo-class and the UA (User Agent) determines via heuristics that the focus should be made evident on the element. (Many browsers show a “focus ring” by default in this case.)
the-focus-visible-pseudo.title: :focus-visible

the-focus-within-pseudo.name: focus-within
the-focus-within-pseudo.summary: The :focus-within CSS pseudo-class represents an element that has received focus or contains an element that has received focus. In other words, it represents an element that is itself matched by the :focus pseudo-class or has a descendant that is matched by :focus. (This includes descendants in shadow trees.)
the-focus-within-pseudo.title: :focus-within

focus-pseudo.name: focus
focus-pseudo.summary: The :focus CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as a form input) that has received focus. It is generally triggered when the user clicks or taps on an element or selects it with the keyboard's "tab" key.
focus-pseudo.title: :focus

general-sibling-combinators.name: general_sibling
general-sibling-combinators.summary: The general sibling combinator (~) separates two selectors and matches the second element only if it follows the first element (though not necessarily immediately), and both are children of the same parent element.
general-sibling-combinators.title: General sibling combinator

relational.name: has
relational.summary: The :has() CSS pseudo-class represents an element if any of the selectors passed as parameters (relative to the :scope of the given element), match at least one element.
relational.title: :has()

the-hover-pseudo.name: hover
the-hover-pseudo.summary: The :hover CSS pseudo-class matches when the user interacts with an element with a pointing device, but does not necessarily activate it. It is generally triggered when the user hovers over an element with the cursor (mouse pointer).

safari_ios.notes: As of Safari for iOS 7.1.2, tapping a clickable element causes the element to enter the :hover state. The element will remain in the :hover state until a different element has entered the :hover state.

the-hover-pseudo.title: :hover

id-selectors.name: id
id-selectors.summary: The CSS ID selector matches an element based on the value of its id attribute. In order for the element to be selected, its id attribute must match exactly the value given in the selector.
id-selectors.title: ID selectors

in-range-pseudo.name: in-range
in-range-pseudo.summary: The :in-range CSS pseudo-class represents an <input> element whose current value is within the range limits specified by the min and max attributes.

chrome.notes: Before Chrome 52, :in-range matched disabled and read-only inputs (see Chromium bug 602568). In Chrome 52, it was changed to only match enabled read-write inputs.

chrome_android.notes: Before Chrome 52, :in-range matched disabled and read-only inputs (see Chromium bug 602568). In Chrome 52, it was changed to only match enabled read-write inputs.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 50, :in-range matched disabled and read-only inputs (see bug 1264157). In Firefox 50, it was changed to only match enabled read-write inputs.

opera.notes: Before Opera 39, :in-range matched disabled and read-only inputs (see Chromium bug 602568). In Opera 39, it was changed to only match enabled read-write inputs.

opera_android.notes: Before Opera 39, :in-range matched disabled and read-only inputs (see Chromium bug 602568). In Opera 39, it was changed to only match enabled read-write inputs.

safari.notes: In Safari, :in-range matched disabled and read-only inputs (see bug 156530). It was later changed to only match enabled read-write inputs.

safari_ios.notes: In Safari, :in-range matched disabled and read-only inputs (see bug 156530). It was later changed to only match enabled read-write inputs.

samsunginternet_android.notes: Before version 6.0, :in-range matched disabled and read-only inputs (see Chromium bug 602568). In version 6.0, it was changed to only match enabled read-write inputs.

webview_android.notes: Before version 52, :in-range matched disabled and read-only inputs (see Chromium bug 602568). In version 52, it was changed to only match enabled read-write inputs.

edge_blink.notes: Before Chrome 52, :in-range matched disabled and read-only inputs (see Chromium bug 602568). In Chrome 52, it was changed to only match enabled read-write inputs.

in-range-pseudo.title: :in-range

indeterminate.name: indeterminate
indeterminate.summary: The :indeterminate CSS pseudo-class represents any form element whose state is indeterminate.
indeterminate.title: :indeterminate

validity-pseudos.name: invalid
validity-pseudos.summary: The :invalid CSS pseudo-class represents any <input> or other <form> element whose contents fail to validate.
validity-pseudos.title: :invalid

validity-pseudos.name: valid
validity-pseudos.summary: The :valid CSS pseudo-class represents any <input> or other <form> element whose contents validate successfully. This allows to easily make valid fields adopt an appearance that helps the user confirm that their data is formatted properly.
validity-pseudos.title: :valid

matches-pseudo.name: is
matches-pseudo.summary: The :is() CSS pseudo-class function takes a selector list as its argument, and selects any element that can be selected by one of the selectors in that list. This is useful for writing large selectors in a more compact form.

chrome.notes: Combinators in the selector list argument may not match correctly (see bug 842157).
Combinators in the selector list argument may not match correctly (see bug 842157).

chrome_android.notes: Combinators in the selector list argument may not match correctly (see bug 842157).

firefox.notes: Enabled by default in Firefox Nightly.

opera.notes: Combinators in the selector list argument may not match correctly (see bug 842157).
Combinators in the selector list argument may not match correctly (see bug 842157).

opera_android.notes: Combinators in the selector list argument may not match correctly (see bug 842157).
Combinators in the selector list argument may not match correctly (see bug 842157).

edge_blink.notes: Combinators in the selector list argument may not match correctly (see bug 842157).
Combinators in the selector list argument may not match correctly (see bug 842157).

matches-pseudo.title: :is() (:matches(), :any())

lang-pseudo.name: lang
lang-pseudo.summary: The :lang() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on the language they are determined to be in.
lang-pseudo.title: :lang()

the-last-child-pseudo.name: last-child
the-last-child-pseudo.summary: The :last-child CSS pseudo-class represents the last element among a group of sibling elements.
the-last-child-pseudo.title: :last-child

last-of-type-pseudo.name: last-of-type
last-of-type-pseudo.summary: The :last-of-type CSS pseudo-class represents the last element of its type among a group of sibling elements.

ie.notes: Internet Explorer treats all unknown elements (such as custom elements) as the same element type.

last-of-type-pseudo.title: :last-of-type

link.name: link
link.summary: The :link CSS pseudo-class represents an element that has not yet been visited. It matches every unvisited <a>, <area>, or <link> element that has an href attribute.
link.title: :link

link.name: visited
link.summary: The :visited CSS pseudo-class represents links that the user has already visited. For privacy reasons, the styles that can be modified using this selector are very limited.
link.title: :visited

grouping.name: list
grouping.summary: The CSS selector list (,) selects all the matching nodes.
grouping.title: Selector list

negation.name: not
negation.summary: The :not() CSS pseudo-class represents elements that do not match a list of selectors. Since it prevents specific items from being selected, it is known as the negation pseudo-class.
negation.title: :not()

nth-child-pseudo.name: nth-child
nth-child-pseudo.summary: The :nth-child() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on their position in a group of siblings.

opera.notes: Before Opera 15, Opera does not handle dynamically inserted elements for :nth-child().

opera_android.notes: Before Opera 15, Opera does not handle dynamically inserted elements for :nth-child().

nth-child-pseudo.title: :nth-child()

nth-last-child-pseudo.name: nth-last-child
nth-last-child-pseudo.summary: The :nth-last-child() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on their position among a group of siblings, counting from the end.
nth-last-child-pseudo.title: :nth-last-child()

nth-last-of-type-pseudo.name: nth-last-of-type
nth-last-of-type-pseudo.summary: The :nth-last-of-type() CSS pseudo-class matches elements of a given type, based on their position among a group of siblings, counting from the end.

ie.notes: Internet Explorer treats all unknown elements (such as custom elements) as the same element type.

nth-last-of-type-pseudo.title: :nth-last-of-type()

nth-of-type-pseudo.name: nth-of-type
nth-of-type-pseudo.summary: The :nth-of-type() CSS pseudo-class matches elements of a given type, based on their position among a group of siblings.

ie.notes: Internet Explorer treats all unknown elements (such as custom elements) as the same element type.

nth-of-type-pseudo.title: :nth-of-type()

only-child-pseudo.name: only-child
only-child-pseudo.summary: The :only-child CSS pseudo-class represents an element without any siblings. This is the same as :first-child:last-child or :nth-child(1):nth-last-child(1), but with a lower specificity.
only-child-pseudo.title: :only-child

only-of-type-pseudo.name: only-of-type
only-of-type-pseudo.summary: The :only-of-type CSS pseudo-class represents an element that has no siblings of the same type.

ie.notes: Internet Explorer treats all unknown elements (such as custom elements) as the same element type.

only-of-type-pseudo.title: :only-of-type

opt-pseudos.name: optional
opt-pseudos.summary: The :optional CSS pseudo-class represents any <input>, <select>, or <textarea> element that does not have the required attribute set on it.
opt-pseudos.title: :optional

opt-pseudos.name: required
opt-pseudos.summary: The :required CSS pseudo-class represents any <input>, <select>, or <textarea> element that has the required attribute set on it.
opt-pseudos.title: :required

out-of-range-pseudo.name: out-of-range
out-of-range-pseudo.summary: The :out-of-range CSS pseudo-class represents an <input> element whose current value is outside the range limits specified by the min and max attributes.
out-of-range-pseudo.title: :out-of-range

placeholder.name: placeholder-shown
placeholder.summary: The :placeholder-shown CSS pseudo-class represents any <input> or <textarea> element that is currently displaying placeholder text.
placeholder.title: :placeholder-shown

rw-pseudos.name: read-only
rw-pseudos.summary: The :read-only CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as input or textarea) that is not editable by the user.
rw-pseudos.title: :read-only

rw-pseudos.name: read-write
rw-pseudos.summary: The :read-write CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as input or textarea) that is editable by the user.
rw-pseudos.title: :read-write

root-pseudo.name: root
root-pseudo.summary: The :root CSS  pseudo-class matches the root element of a tree representing the document. In HTML, :root represents the <html> element and is identical to the selector html, except that its specificity is higher.
root-pseudo.title: :root

the-scope-pseudo.name: scope
the-scope-pseudo.summary: The :scope CSS pseudo-class represents elements that are a reference point for selectors to match against.

firefox.notes: Firefox 55 removes support for <style scoped> but not for the :scope pseudo-class, which is still supported. <style scoped> made it possible to explicitly set up element scopes, but ongoing discussions about the design of this feature as well as lack of other implementations resulted in the decision to remove it.

firefox_android.notes: Firefox 55 removes support for <style scoped> but not for the :scope pseudo-class, which is still supported. <style scoped> made it possible to explicitly set up element scopes, but ongoing discussions about the design of this feature as well as lack of other implementations resulted in the decision to remove it.

the-scope-pseudo.title: :scope

the-target-pseudo.name: target
the-target-pseudo.summary: The :target CSS pseudo-class represents a unique element (the target element) with an id matching the URL's fragment.
the-target-pseudo.title: :target

type-selectors.name: type
type-selectors.summary: The CSS type selector matches elements by node name. In other words, it selects all elements of the given type within a document.
type-selectors.title: Type selectors

the-universal-selector.name: universal
the-universal-selector.summary: The CSS universal selector (*) matches elements of any type.
the-universal-selector.title: Universal selectors

zero-matches.name: where
zero-matches.summary: The :where() CSS pseudo-class function takes a selector list as its argument, and selects any element that can be selected by one of the selectors in that list.

firefox.notes: Enabled by default in Firefox Nightly.

zero-matches.title: :where()
